III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10165 Resident nutrition
Section (2) Special diets shall be prescribed only by a physician. A
Description resident who has been prescribed a special diet by a physician
shall be provided such diet.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff at the facility are provided with a list of all the residents that
have allergies. On the list is Youth A who is allergic to peanuts,
strawberries, watermelon and dairy. Today, youths received a
meal that included a taco and other dairy products. It is unknown if
Youth A was accommodated with a different meal due to his
allergies.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on June 4, 2025. Staff 1
reported he is unaware if Youth A was given a dairy product within
his dinner on June 2, 2025. He reported he assumed Youth A was
given the same meal as all the other residents, which was tacos
with cheese. Staff 1 reported Youth A cannot have dairy, and he is
concerned the facility is not following Youth A’s dietary
restrictions. Staff 1 reported he did not give Youth A his meal tray
that day and does not know who provided the meal tray to Youth
A. When asked if Youth A made a complaint to him about this,
Staff 1 denied Youth A ever making a complaint about this to him.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 6,
2025. Youth A reported his food allergies are taken seriously at
the facility. He confirmed he did eat tacos the other day but denied
there being any allergy concerns. Youth A reported he gets a
specialized tray of food that has no nuts, dairy, watermelon, or
strawberries on it. He reported if he ever has a concern with his
food, he will report it but he can’t remember a time of this
happening.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 6,
2025. Staff 2 reported he was aware of Youth A’s food allergies.
He reported Youth A’s allergies are listed on the pod and in the
kitchen to make sure he gets a safe meal to eat. Staff 2 reported
everyone at the facility takes allergies seriously. He reported
Youth A tries to get out of eating the meal he gets when he
doesn’t like what is provided to him. Staff 2 reported if there is
ever a concern with his meal, Youth A is vocal with staff about
this.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 6,
2025. Staff 3 reported he is aware of Youth A’s food allergies and
2

noted the allergies are posted on the pod. He reported there have
been no reported concerns of Youth A receiving a meal he could
not eat.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 6,
2025. Staff 4 reported the facility takes youth allergies very
seriously. He reported Youth A’s allergies are posted in the
kitchen and the pod, so everyone is aware. Staff 4 reported Youth
A gets a specialized tray for his allergies. He reported he has not
witnessed or heard of Youth A getting food that he is allergic to.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on June 6, 2025. The cafeteria
area was viewed, and Youth A’s name was posted with his
allergies within the kitchen area. The pod Youth A is on was also
viewed and on the white board was Youth A’s name with his listed
allergies for the team to be able to see.
Documents Reviewed:
- Youth A’s file- Youth A’s admission file notes all of his
food allergies from his initial admission.
- Facility Resident Management Policy- This policy notes
all youth should receive an adequate diet.
Analysis The facility is following Youth A’s food restrictions and providing
him proper meals. The staff that were interviewed were
knowledgeable of Youth A’s food allergies and it was posted in the
pod and the kitchen. Youth A reported in his interview that the
facility has been following his food restrictions.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10171 Resident confinement room; approved
Section usage.
Description A facility approved to use a resident confinement room may place
a resident in this room for the following reasons:
(e) For behavior management/confinement when a resident is in
danger of harming self or others.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth B has not been out of his room in two weeks; he is being
labeled as Status A which means he had a behavioral incident
while being in the facility, however, Youth B has had no behavioral
incidents since being in there and there is no paperwork indicating
that there was a behavioral incident.
Investigation Interviews:
3

Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on June 4, 2025. Staff 1
reported he does not work very much on Youth B’s pod but noted
Youth B made the complaint to him directly about how he has not
been out of his room for two weeks. He reported Youth B stated
he is not allowed out of his room because of the criminal charges
he has against him and denied it being about his behaviors. Staff
1 reported he has never seen Youth B have any behavior
concerns and is concerned the facility is locking Youth B in his
room for no reason.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 6,
2025. Youth B reported he is on a specialized program from when
he first arrived at the facility. He reported that means he was
allowed out of his room at different times than the other youth.
Youth B reported now he is allowed out with the other youth but
chooses to stay more in his room because he does not get along
with the other youth and they make negative comments towards
him. He reported when staff hear the negative comments they will
intervene. Youth A denied being locked in his room for two weeks
straight.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 6,
2025. Youth A reported he is in the same pod as Youth B. He
reported Youth B was on a specialized programming when he first
arrived where he was out of his room at different times than the
other youth. Youth A reported now Youth B is allowed out with the
other youth, but he chooses to stay in his room more. He does not
know why Youth B chooses to stay in his room. Youth A denied
having any concerns about youth being secluded in their rooms at
the facility.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 6,
2025. Staff 2 reported he has worked with Youth B since he got to
the facility and denied Youth B being locked in his room for two
weeks. He reported Youth B was allowed out of his room at
different points but always chose to go back into his room
because he did not get along with his peers. Staff 2 reported
Youth B was on restricted programming when he first arrived due
to the severity of his charges but was allowed out of his room at
different points throughout the day.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 6,
2025. Staff 3 reported he did not work very much with Youth B. He
reported he has witnessed Youth B out of his room though. Staff
3 reported Youth B was on programming when he first arrived due
to his specific charges and heard that he also chose to be in his
room due to peer interactions.
4

Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on June 6,
2025. Staff 4 reported he has worked a lot with Youth B and
denied Youth B being locked in his room for two weeks straight.
He reported Youth B was on a specialized program due to the
severity of his charges, so he was coming out of his room at
different times than the other youth. Staff 4 reported that Youth B
has also requested to be in his room more at times due to the fear
of the other youth in the pod.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility Policy- Safety and Security- The facility has a
formal classification system that determines and separates
(within program and building limitations) aggressive
individuals, first time offenders, suicidal youth, and high-risk
detainees. The purpose of the classification system is to
determine placement in living units as well as the mobility
of residents inside/outside the building.
o The policy breaks it down to the A Status which
Youth B was classified as. This is due to Youth B is
determined to be high risk to the community, high
bond, and aggressive charges towards adults. This
means Youth B is restricted to movements to room,
living area and day room, and meal within his room.
- Youth B’s File- Youth B was admitted into the facility on
05/25/2025. The charges he is detained on are criminal
sexual conduct in the second degree and felony assault
with a dangerous weapon.
o Notes from Administrator about program review
▪ May 27, 2025- Youth B has severe charges
and claiming threats by other residents.
Placed on Modified Pod Program/ 1 hour
activity.
▪ May 30, 2025- Youth B remains on Modified
Pod Program/ 1 hour activity due to charges
and claims of threats by peers.
▪ June 1, 2025- Youth B remains on Modified
Pod Program/ 1 hour activity due to charges
and claims of threats by peers.
▪ June 6, 2025- Moved to Modified Pod
Program/ Gym only. Youth B is claiming that
5

he is not afraid for his safety and that his
peers are not a threat.
- Room Observation Sheet for Youth B dated 05/25/2025-
06/02/2025- There was documented checks for Youth B
every fifteen minutes with at least an hour outside of his
room. There was authorization by supervisor every twelve
hours.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance. When Youth A was first
admitted into the facility due to his severity of charges, he was put
on room restrictions but was allowed out of his room at certain
periods. Youth A is currently reporting he has been choosing to
stay in his room at times because he does not like the other youth.
Youth A never being allowed out of his room.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
